>From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>

>John, does this mean you will be using JNEAT?  Or are you going to
>write your own, or perhaps use another Java version of NEAT?

I'm thinking hybrid.  I want to do a more passive system, like SETI@home, 
where clients ping the server to get work to do.  That way, I can put 
computers to work that are outside my firewall.

I'm actually thinking of making the client/worker component a java applet in 
a web page.  The page contains the network topology and input/output sample 
embedded as parameters to the applet.  The applet runs until it produces a 
result, and then that result is posted back to the server via a submit form 
that is automatically activated as soon as the evaluation is done.  One 
reason for this is that the applet is (hopefully) automatically updated on 
every client as soon as I update it on the server.

I'm picturing an applet that shows 6 squares (all the same size).  One is 
the original input sample, shown at, say, 3 inches square.  The next is the 
higher-resolution expected output, also 3"x3" but with more pixels.  In a 
third square, the output of the network is painted into the corresponding 
location in the square, thus it is always changing.  The fourth square is 
the difference between the actual output and the expected output (the error 
image).  The fifth and sixth squares are spatial error transformations 
performed on the error image.  They will highlight certain kinds of errors, 
like stairstepping and halos.

Then, on the form in the web page is a field that holds the current running 
fitness value.  With each completion of a pass (at different levels of 
enlargement), it will update the spatial error images and then use them to 
help with creating a fitness value.  Once the process is complete, a 
JavaScript function will automatically post/submit the form, and the results 
are sent back to the server.  The reply, of course, is the next 
network/sample to evaluate.  And the graphics are mostly eye-candy to keep 
it interesting.  It would probably be faster without it, but because it 
provides feedback on how good it is (or is not) doing, it helps with the 
patience factor.

When the data is sent to the server, it is received by a perl or php script 
which dumps it into a database (sql or xml or file or something).  It then 
checks to see if all of the networks have been evaluated against that 
particular sample.  If so, it then calls out to an external NEAT executable 
that evaluates the scores and determines which specimens would reproduce, 
and whether enough evaluation has been done so far, and all that jazz.  If 
we have done enough, it generates a new population.  Either way, it produces 
a new input/output sample.  Future requests then evaluate against a new 
input/output sample and possibly a new generation of specimens.

The back-end will probably be a mix of perl or php and either C++ or Java.   
The one part is modified existing NEAT code that does the checks to see who 
should reproduce, and does the actual creation of the next generation from 
the current generation based on fitness values.  Everything else is done 
using whatever gets the job done fastest.  Meaning, easiest to write.
